topic.title: SHA1 Collision a Concern for BitTorrent-Based Technologies?
topic.body:
I don't know much about this subject, but I feel like all such projects won't be worthy of my donated dollars until all concerns are laid to rest with a better hash algorithm.

Here's a link to a deep discussion on this issue below.

https://github.com/bittorrent/bittorrent.org/issues/58

Edit: In the comments I was reassured ZeroNet devs were wise to use a better hash algorithm to boot. They'll be receiving funds from me soon.

> [nofish](#comment_889_1J3rJ8ecnwH2EPYa6MrgZttBNc61ACFiCj): ZeroNet using sha512/256, so it should be safe for another ~10years

> [waterrabbit](#comment_125_1LxkfGxtWhktAJ5WJ9ZnKxksTSH37qm8cC): >>> import base64
> >>> import hashlib
> 
> >>> s = hashlib.sha512("Replace SHA-1 with stronger message digest functions!").digest()
> >>> base64.b32encode(s)
> 
> 'EYVH4MBTKSZQOARCINCZZXUARJFP2SY4GXZITGS27VSZKUANE27XMNUZZ52O6UP6GUKS3LMVSGWYVBKAL3CLY5AXKN4C4HDYLBY4J2A='
> >>> new_infohash = base64.b32encode(s).lower().strip("=")
> >>> new_urn = "bsha"
> >>> new_maglink = "magnet:?xt=urn:%s:%s" % (new_urn, new_infohash)
> >>> new_maglink
> 
> 'magnet:?xt=urn:bsha:eyvh4mbtkszqoarcinczzxuarjfp2sy4gxzitgs27vszkuane27xmnuzz52o6up6guks3lmvsgwyvbkal3cly5axkn4c4hdylby4j2a'

topic.title: Everyone should stop downloading with Chrome
topic.body:
The reason is simple.

Upward of seven years ago I've found out Chrome corrupts large downloads a very large percentage of the time.

Checksum check any file measured in gigabytes downloaded via HTTP through Chrome.

I bet you've been installing corrupted software for a while now.

Save all headaches and download with Firefox or other Gecko browsers. I have no faith in Webkit or Blink browsers as this bug had never and will never be fixed, no matter how many times you report it.

I bet uploads can experience corruption as well.

topic.title: Could ZeroNet circumvent the internet?
topic.body:
If the internet we knew and loved was trashed, and what remained was locked down to a whitelist, would information be able to pass along horizontally instead of vertically? In other words, would information be able to pass exclusively via LAN if WAN access was completely prohibited? When DHT gets built into ZeroNet, would this become an option?

Let's forget about mesh networking ever becoming ubiquitous. What we're left with is regular WiFi access points, which should be enough.

Leave everything out of the discussion except for what it would take for information to travel in a purely horizontal fashion.

topic.title: Question Before I Buy an SDXC Card
topic.body:
Can I install ZeroNet to SDXC without root on any phone?

I can't seed more than a few videos without high capacity storage.

Also, although I can find downloaded files in my local storage's ZeroNet directory, zites lack a list of files you're seeding or leeching other than what you've brought to the zite, so if you forget or just don't know the filename, it takes a few minutes to search through the site to find the filename, which I need to search for the file in my local storage.

A few devs with no affiliation to KopyKate BIG were saying the option is on the zite to delete the file right there. No. It. Is. Not. Were not just talking about own large files. We're talking about other's large files.

Just because you can vaguely read the code or its comments doesn't mean you know the extent of the function. There is no option on the site itself to delete large files that other users brought to the site and it's horribly inconvenient.

I'm only seeding what large files I've brought to ZeroUpload and KopyKate BIG, because file deletion is a chore thus far.

If zite owners want more seeding, then put the option on your zite to remove other people's large files from your zite's folder on local storage and make a list of files being seeded or leeched brought to the zite by all users.

"Show data directory" still doesn't work on any Android device. I've tested this on two completely different phones. The feature broke some time ago.

topic.title: Zites Should Be Taggable and Filterable
topic.body:
Some of us don't want to visit zites with clearnet dependencies, because there are legitimate personal security concerns and there can be very real cybersecurity issues with them. We've had a taste of this with a tk domain used by a popular zite, but without incident since the redirect was only asking sensitive questions be given voluntarily.

Some of us don't want to visit zites with focus on fetishes of varying legality across the globe that may automatically download such media upon clicking, because, for instance, lolicon is illegal in France and a French proxy especially can't have lolicon.

Some of us don't want recreational drug selling zites, especially in proxies. The war on drugs is bananas with bullets and imprisonment if you aren't fatally shot by a douchebag agent or cop with a tiny penis. That is a thing.


I could probably think of more examples, but let's start with that.


Can ZeroNet have an optional automatic preemtive filter for single user and multi user modes defined by the person in control of the device running ZeroNet? Provide an option to block or warn of zites untagged by their owners in their languages? The languages part can matter when a zite is tagged, but a person who might not like the zite doesn't receive a needed tag in their language. This might also save on restricted bandwidth and/or capped data.

Zite owners could in this case provide their own tag list that gets downloaded and read by the ZeroNet client, and before content and media are downloaded, provide a prompt to proceed to the zite or go back for single user mode and in multi user mode just block the zite but log the request. Kaffiene.bit already has zite owner volunteered tags.

That option to block or warn will gently encourage zite owners to tag their zites if they want more cautionary people to seed instead of avoid for not knowing the content or behavior of the zite.

Zite owners don't go through any trouble to pretend their zite has any content or dependencies other than what content or dependencies their zites have. It will be added encouragement if all ZeroNet search engines can pickup the tag lists of zites automatically upon crawling them for those who want to visit particular categories of zites, thus zites gain exposure through all search engines that index them. Search engines that don't want to index zites tagged under particular categories can run on a tag blacklist defined by those search engine owners, like I believe kaffie does for kaffiene.bit. It could be automated for all search engines through the ZeroNet API if this idea becomes a feature.

No manual blacklisting of zites like we already have would be required.

If we already have something more than manually blacklisting zites, I haven't heard of nor seen it. Forgive me if this exact idea and no less is already implemented.

topic.title: Zer0rigin
topic.body:
I dream of open collaboration to create music and publish it on ZeroNet.

We can become disruptive in how music is created, distributed and perhaps monetized.

On ZeroMedium I published my political poem Obeyin' the Rules, not expecting to make a career of it, because that was the first time I felt like I wrote something really good that may have musical value to it. When I will write that good again, I don't know, so sharing it became more important than a career pursuit. What I want to see is someone make a musical track of it with attribution to me and publish it to ZeroNet only. If monetized for personal gain, I ask for a 50/50 split, but I won't make a fuss whatever you end up doing with it. The message is more important than money. The truth should always be free, but effort can be rewarded and we can all benefit. The three don't have to conflict. Take the optional browser mining employed by bigcat.tk, CoinHive, for example. We can set new examples for entertainment industries to follow while growing ZeroNet funding and user count.

0rigin.bit, zerorigin.bit and zer0rigin.bit are available.

https://dotbit.me/

Krixano got the idea to make a lyrics zite. I think we'll soon be on our way. I just wanted to be sure this ball is rolling.

Think of it what you will, but I think it's just a matter of time before this happens, so we can at least make sure it's done right, and we can generate funds for ZeroNet development as a result. There have been a few markets that have already come to ZeroNet, but none like this.

topic.title: ZeroNet: To Gain Funding and Popularity...
topic.body:
Seek out websites and organizations that stand for net neutrality and are under existential threat but are neither owned nor reselling services by corporations in favor of killing net neutrality, find contact info for the owners, and direct message these owners via email or Twitter. I think we should maintain secrecy over seeking out these people so the ISPs don't go after harming ZeroNet traffic, as I'm sure they could block ZeroNet.io, trackers and GitHub access.

@Nofish: Provide incentives for them to fund ZeroNet development by listing their sites under the MORE SITES list on ZeroHello or a separate sponsors page on ZeroSites, or make a whole new site listing sponsors. Mastodon's Patreon page provides an incentive for sponsors to make large monthly donations.

We can show them new means of revenue such as CoinHive or other JavaScript miners. We should make sure they don't bring the bad qualities of the clearnet to ZeroNet, such as ads.

I've had no problem contacting David Michael Latt on MySpace to hate on him for making ripoff films before the spark of originality for Sharknado and getting a response telling me to calm down (I was an angsty teen), had a conversation with Ralph Baer through email about maybe working on an invention although I chickened out (was way ahead of technological feasibility at the time anyway), told the owner of BitChute about ZeroNet via DMs and other decentralizing technologies via a mention which sparked some interest, talked to a developer about making a custom app and I'm sure we've all seen how responsive people from all walks of life are to email and Twitter over the past decade, so it's apparent to me that anyone can contact movers and shakers to set things in motion. I'm neither more important nor more influential than the rest of you are.

Even if you guys don't contact movers and shakers, I most certainly will put effort into it, but that's no power unique to me, so I would encourage those with good language and communication skills to give it a shot in standard letter format. I'll do my research to make sure who I contact has no oligarch overlords. I'm aiming for independents who have made strides and have gained a following all by themselves. Whether you like, dislike or don't care about this, I will put in the effort.

We can discuss here who we should contact and how to persuade them diplomatically. We can start with those who fill niches that haven't been filled on ZeroNet properly or have never been filled on ZeroNet before.

Cheers. I hope you'll all have a joyful future no matter what life throws at you.

topic.title: Proving The Existence Of A Second Private Key That Decrypts a Message Encrypted With The RSA Encryption Algorithm
topic.body:
"While taking a course in cryptography 6 years ago I stumbled upon a problem that kept me awake at night for many nights.

In school we learn that the RSA encryption algorithm consists of one public key and one private key. I've asked several professors if there could be a second private key that decrypts all messages in the same way as the intended private key and I've always received a negative answer.

And yet I stumbled upon two private keys in one particular example. I delved into the Mathematics behind the RSA algorithm and I found out that in fact there are at least two keys in every single example. I not only managed to prove the existence of a second private key but I was also able to find two different formulas for obtaining the second key.

One of the formulas requires knowledge of phi(n)/2 where phi(n) is Euler's Totient Function.

If d1 is the intended private key and (n, e) is the public key then the second key d2 can be found using the following formula:

d2*e = phi(n)/2

Here's the full paper: https://marinaibrishimova.net/docs/otherkeys.pdf

Currently, I'm looking into ways of obtaining phi(n)/2 without having to factor n"

https://badbytes.blogspot.com/2017/12/proving-existence-of-second-private-key.html?m=1

topic.title: Movers & Shakers
topic.body:
They are the vloggers on YouTube, independent journalists, Twitch and YouTube Gaming livestreamers, to name a few. You can find one vlogger with nearly 6 million subscribers who defends net neutrality. These people have pull with users and millions of dollars, of which I'm sure they don't mind sparing a tiny amount of for ZeroNet development.The KopyKate BIG dev and the ZeroNet dev Tamas AKA @Nofish need to have private talks with these people. Figure out what they need to be satisfied with ZeroNet so they start mirroring their content here.

One thing is that Linus Tech Tips videos are already on KopyKate. They need to be sure only official uploads of theirs exist on KopyKate or a fork and that a revenue is generated for them. Of course ZeroNet viewers get a copy of a video on their file system, but they're not easily found by amateurs (I can find them myself, but it's still not better than browsing KopyKate or ZeroUp), and in all fairness, there are many ways to save a local copy from YouTube anyway without ads playing, so I see no loss for movers and shakers using ZeroNet compared with YouTube. They need to know that. Viewers will watch videos in the browser where the JS miner runs, simply out of convenience, though interactions and features will also encourage more time spent on a video's page.

I don't want this to become a thing where copyright becomes a big issue, as it would become unnecessary overhead when copyright infringement is really easy to do, especially with YouTube, so a user experience that enhances browsing/watching/interacting is key.

1509111564_1LXSmRHtTjeKqDCSrZ8GLJUPRimrL.body:
You need to seed the entire size of the file. As others said, it depends on if people like it enough and decide to be long term seeders or long enough for the file to ride along a series of new peers downloading the whole file, becoming seeders long enough to keep the download alive and if their devices are off that's fine because they resume seeding when the device is turned back on and running the program that does the file sharing. Oftentimes torrent programs show you MB uploaded. On zites, however, you're presented with a number representing how many times you've seeded a file, if not also MB uploaded. They both represent the same in different fashion.

After your download becomes popular, you can delete your locally stored copy and redownload it, but that goofs with some zites as you may lose permission to edit the title and any other information you may attach to the file in the site's index. It can also interfere with the ability to delete the file and then the only fix is to overwrite the file with one by the same name, then those permissions come back. This is the case with ZeroUp.

> [realkittykate](#comment_52_17H8EGEoNF1z2AXFtXmBQJLHTmh7gMGzzS): The biggest strength of ZeroNet is the ease of access and its web interface. You can even create a web proxy and give freenet users access to the blockchain.. without them having to download the sites to their computer.. kinda like how Bitcoin users can either open up a new wallet by downloading the entire 80gb blockchain, or simply signing up with an online e-wallet provider. The fact is, decentralization will never replace centalization. It has its ups and downs. I'd go as far as to say that the only reason it exists in the first place is because of government censorship. Besides circumventing censorship, I'd say the only use for p2p that I can think of it would be, having the ability to host your own content for free, without paying for web hosting and/or cloud storage, but that's about it. So yeah, I'm sticking with Zeronet.. precisely because of its ability to bridge the p2p world and the HTTP world.

Of course ZeroNet will never replace clearnet. Centralism is working well for those in greatest control. We just have our optimisms even if they're unrealistic expectations in some cases.

For instance, getting your IRL friends and family to try ZeroNet and stay is near impossible, but advancements like recently added bigfile support and further refinement of zites will lower that difficulty.

Right now there's a lot left to be desired, but the community is getting there. In a year I expect ZeroNet will become as popular as BitTorrent. I think that will be enough time for the entire ecosystem to become more diverse, complete and compelling.

It pretty much begins with zites emulating what the clearnet provides, even though they won't have the same background operations.

File sharing, video sharing, music sharing, image sharing, social networks, wikis, blogs, journalism, mail, chat, imageboards, URL shorteners, what have you. ZeroNet is on its way, though I think some of them need a little more refinement or features at present.

We're being realistic, but we're a ways off from the ZeroNet ecosystem being compelling to a wider audience. There's lots of room for it to grow out of feeling very niche. Then we'll see how popular ZeroNet can be.

I'm thinking a broadband teaming router would allow your device to sit between an online modem and an offline router so you don't have to share your broadband connection, also allowing a ZeroNet exclusive router or mesh to exist.

So you'd have an online modem feed into WAN1 of the teaming router and a router with an open hotspot but no WAN connection feed into WAN2 of the teaming router. Your computer and/or phone would be under that teaming router in the topology tree. Neighbors connect to the router with an open hotspot would then only be able to connect to your device through peer discovery.

Modem \
|||||||||||||||| => Teaming router -> your device(s)
OOHR || /--> Neighbor devices

When ZeroNet gets DHT and peer discovery, I'll give this a try.

> [htgozn](#comment_6_1J58Rie679DVSuKB1iDyFFTbzmaMaY2bt2): Here are a few of my suggestions that I feel are missing from KopyKat   [...]

It shouldn't be SFW tags. NSFW videos are what need to be tagged since they make a shorter list, and that's the classical design of Diaspora and Mastodon to tag NSFW content, not SFW content.

Create the five star rating system on one condition: The average rating only factors in ratings from people you subscribe to.

This way spam accounts are excluded outright from gaming/spamming the ratings system.

Also, this would create a more personalized rating for videos since you are assumed to share views with those you subscribe to.

But then I'm thinking categories will matter here. If you watch someone's videos of a category that is irrelevant to another, then maybe make subscribing granular down to the category level, so then liking someone's movies doesn't imply you like their politics.

Here's a paraphrase I shared on Google+:

Websites need to get their ideas from me. I've solved the problem with video ratings spam. It's this simple: You subscribe to people on a granular level, by category. The category of videos you subscribe to factors in their ratings of other people's videos of that same category. This way, if you like someone's taste in music but not their politics, that doesn't influence the average ratings of political videos.

Boom! Spam-B-Gone!

Convenience, Conversations, Closed Captions, Crypto Currencies, Content Creation, Conversions and Cooperation will make Copyright a thing of the past.

I'm all for abolishing copyright. My post might not have been clear on that. My idea was to make it a non-issue for content creators to the point that nobody sees the need for the copyright laws to be enforced, because with KopyKate BIG or a fork it would be made absolutely moot.

Those videos I've shared? I got them from YouTube using a tool that probably everybody or essentially nobody doing the same knows about, and it's so easy. It always will be. There's nothing to fight, like punching thin air. In the long run, copyright enforcers hurt their potential customer base with punishment that's not only unnecessary, but extremely heavy-handed, and it is a greedy pursuit just like the war on drugs or the homeless pretending to serve justice when underneath it all there's a service issue coming from the almighty, anointed, officials whose jobs depend on corrupt industries trying to make everyone's lives harder.

So, I think the only solution is to have the ultimate video sharing website where the user experience is top notch, such as where KopyKate BIG is headed. People who would remove the miner from their filesystem are probably saving videos from YouTube or digging around ZeroNet folders. Whatever. Let be. That's not a common thing, and I think if the miner doesn't hurt video performance, then most people will be fine with it on. It would be for the sole purpose of creating an incentive for content creators to arrive, promoting ZeroNet to their millions of fans and chipping in for ZeroNet development.

But, it's up to the individual web developer and Nofish what they feel is necessary. I will have no issue no matter what they or you decide is the next step.

I was thinking what I've said would be an answer for what ZeroNet needs, but if you don't agree, I'm alright with that.
